text.description1: Bonaire, ook wel Diver’s Paradise genoemd, is een van de mooiste eilanden in om te duiken in het Caribisch gebied. Jaarlijks komen hier talloze toeristen genieten van het moois dat Bonaire te bieden heeft.
text.description2: Wat wil jij dien? Koraal, haaien, roggen, schildpadden of werkt de maan met je mee en ga je voor een duik met Ostracods?

text.description1: Enter next to the pier at Yellow Submarine and head straight out to the reef. Top of reef is around 6 meters, bottom is around 30 meters. Watch out for boat traffic.
text.description2: Very typical Bonaire reef. Often good sightings of fish here. Corals abundant, but less healthy than other places.

text.description1: The reef is located at the bay of the same name and is easily accessible from the shore. The reef stretches out enormously so it may take a while to explore every corner. Be careful, there can be a strong current out of the area.
text.description2: When diving on cai you might encounter turtles, eagle rays and moray eels. Do you also notice the piles of shells?

text.description1: This dive site lives up to its name: Something Special because it is just that. An incredible amount of biodiversity calls this reef home; it’s filled with an incredible mixture of hard and soft corals. The sandy areas have discarded rubble that acts as a fantastic artificial reef.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Calabas Reef is the house reef for the popular Divi Flamingo Beach Resort and sits right out in front of it. A healthy reef system with lots of turtles, groupers and even a seahorse or two.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: This is located at the resort of the same name. Right between Front Porche (31) and Harbour Village. So you can let the dive flow into one of the other 2 spots.
text.description2: On the sand you might come across rays. Furthermore, you will see the typical life that Bonaire has to offer.

text.description1: A small jetty runs along the northern section of this dive site where plenty of fish hide like octopus, crabs, lobsters, etc. An easily accessible shore dive suitable for all levels of divers.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: One of the most popular dive sites in all of Bonaire, Buddy’s Reef is a very easily accessible shore dive perfect for beginners and experienced divers. It sits right off the popular Buddy’s Dive Resort and is their house reef.
text.description2: You will see the resident tarpon that lives here plus octopus, squid, sea turtles, and tons of reef fish species.

text.description1: La Machaca is a wreck, a 30 meter swim from the pier of Captain Don’s Habitat’s covered reef, so you need permission to dive there. The wreck is located at a depth of 14 meters, if you follow the rope you will come across a second wreck, tugboat Hesper.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Front Porche is a shore accessible dive site not well known for its outstanding reef, but for its scraps. The site is littered with steel pipes, wreck parts, and old machinery. This interesting mix of artificial reef attracts a wide array of marine life.
text.description2: Living in and around the wreckage are nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, anemones, and grouper.

text.description1: This spot is named after the research done here on the growth of corals on specially designed grids. Also nice for a night dive or snorkeling adventure.
text.description2: Don’t forget to check in with your buddy at the local resort/dive center before enjoying the underwater life.

text.description1: From the resort of the same name you can dive into the water from the beach or from the boat. Beautiful reef puts different lives. Be careful not to dive into the harbor entrance!
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot is located next to the similar restaurant. The reef slopes gently before the wall really starts. Drop off your gear at the water, park your car and start the dive!
text.description2: A relatively untouched reef! Full of both hard and soft corals and all the life you can find on this.

text.description1: Captain Don’s Habitat is one of the most famous dive resorts in Bonaire. The house reef that sits right off from the resort is a very popular and easily accessible dive site with a healthy reef system and tons of marine life. A great site to have a night dive.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Cliff is considered one of the best dive spots on Bonaire for macro photography. Another easy entry shore dive this site does not disappoint as it has a wall running along the left side of the dive site that drops to over 22 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Located in Hamlet Oasis south of Dive Friends Hamlet shop. Marked with a pin. Can be entered from Cliff dive site (Hamlet Dive Friends) or From La Machaca dive site (Captain Don’s).
text.description2: Great site with lots of marine life in the shallows. Seahorses and octopus both day and night, as well as typical reef fish.

text.description1: Unlike a lot of the shore dive locations on the island on Bonaire which have hard limestone entry points, 18 Palm is an easy sandy beach access point and two freshwater showers to rinse your gear at the end of your dive.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Small wall owes its name to the small wall, which runs from approximately 12 to 24 meters and is located 25 meters from the coast. It is an extremely colorful spot, often visited by photographers. Please note, this site can only be reached from the water because the entrance is from private property.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot owes its name to the pillar that Captain Don named after a friend as a wedding gift. The divesite looks very much like Andre I and Andrea II.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Just down the beach from its sister site, the Andrea II, the Andrea I is most well known for its beautiful coral formations from the plate coral that call this reef home. Easily accessible from shore, this is a shallow reef dive and great for snorkeling and beginning divers.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: An easily accessible shore dive location with areas of shade and parking not far from the entry point. This is a large dive site so it never feels crowded here.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: White Hole is located in front of Lac Bay. You can easily get here by boat or by wading a good distance through the bay. The name is derived from the white sand plain.
text.description2: Besides the standard life you will see tarpons and turtles here, but also rays and the occasional shark.

text.description1: Sitting just across the street from the airport, Windsock is an excellent easy entry shore dive great for all levels of divers. A shallow, sandy plateau is followed by a healthy reef structure full of marine life.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: When you drive from Sorobon to the east coast, on the left side there is a deserted shrimp fishing house. When the fence stops, drive in on a sandy road. At the end you can park the car and walk towards the entrance, which is a shallow bay at the shoreline.
text.description2: This site is near to Turtle City. This site is also full of turtles. You can also sport Caribbean reef sharks.

text.description1: The reef is located on Klein Bonaire, so visit it by boat. It is named after Ebo Domacassé, (one of) the first certified diving instructor of Bonaire.
text.description2: It is a steep reef where you can find all the typical life of Klein Bonaire. Jumy, descend and enjoy your dive!

text.description1: The dive site is named after Corporal Robert W. Meiss. It is a typical dive site like Bonaire has many. It is also a popular beach! So combine your dive with sun, sea, beach, snorkeling and a good BBQ.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Keepsake is a nice dive site on Klein Bonaire that is suitable for every diver. It has a sandy bottom with hills and gullies. There is a beautiful drop-off of 12 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot is located in front of the Santa Barbara district and is therefore not accessible from the shore. Time for a boat dive! The wall here continues from 10 to about 40 meters.
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: Another great shore dive in Bonaire, especially nice for photographers due to the sheer diversity of marine life found here. You’ll be greeted underwater first by a sandy plateau and the reef starts just a bit further out.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: This dive site is an easily accessible shore dive right outside of the downtown area. There is a latter for easy entry and exit from the water. An extremely easy dive site to navigate and great for all levels of divers.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: This spot is not among the highlights of Klein Bonaire. Because the water taxi to Klein Bonaire stops here, it is a much visited spot by beachgoers and day trippers.
text.description2: With a bit of luck you will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and many fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: This is the house reef of the hotel/apartment of the same name. It is a wide sandy area before the wall really starts. If you are not a guest, only accessible by boat.
text.description2: On the sand you might come across rays. Furthermore, you will see the typical life that Bonaire has to offer.

text.description1: Kalli’s Reef is a site for boat diving. You can get there from the shore, although getting into the water is not easy. You leave the water in the middle of the adjacent dive site
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Sampler is the northernmost dive site on Klein Bonaire and a much visited site. Flirt with the friendly angelfish living here and enjoy the reef.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot starts off a bit boring, but once the dropoff starts it makes up for everything. There are numerous terraces at different depths, each with a different kind of life.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Knife is a beautiful diving site with a long shallow area, also very suitable for beginners. The site is located on Klein Bonaire, the dropoff starts at 10 meters and continues to 40.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Sara’s Smile is the house reef of Belmar Private Oceanfront Apartments, so if you dive from the shore you need permission. A nice reef and after the dive you will certainly emerge with a “smile“.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This dive site is located at the beginning of the northern route and is named after diving physician Jefferson C. Davis who died here. Note the large step down.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Under the watchful eye of a Divi tree you dive here at one of the southern spots of Klein Bonaire. You reach this steeply sloping reef only by boat.
text.description2: You will encounter a lot of typical life for Bonaire here. Seahorses are regularly spotted here, search for them!

text.description1: The reef starts nicely at shallow depths and is therefore good for snorkeling. In addition, you have a steep wall with many inlets and tunnels where you can find a lot of life.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Located at the “Witch’s Hut“. Good parking and easy entry from a stone path and across a sandy beach. Well sheltered. Great macro site. Lots of sponges.
text.description2: Lots of sponges. Typical hard and soft coral. Lots of macro subjects throughout the site including the sand areas.

text.description1: This site is, how could it be otherwise, located in front of a pile of stones on the island of Klein Bonaire. A nice diving site that is also very suitable for shallow diving.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot starts with a shallow reef, nice for beginning divers or snorkeling. For the more experienced divers, at about 37 meters the 2nd reef starts.
text.description2: At this spot you can sometimes encounter a nurse shark on the sand, especially protected under a piece of reef.

text.description1: Joanne’s Sunchi (or Joanne’s Kiss) is a beautiful dive site with a deep dropoff. Along this dropoff where a lot of coral grows, there are sand ridges that extend to depth.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This is the house reef of the resort of the same name here on Bonaire. It is a beautiful sandy plateau before the wall starts at 15m. Very nice facilities for divers.
text.description2: Register for the dive at the local dive center and then enjoy all the beauty this spot has to offer!

text.description1: With its soft corals and sponges, this wall is a real delight for the underwater photographer. The site is therefore named after photographer Carl Roessler. The wnad runs from 10 to 40 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: ’The Lake’ is actually an ocean dive site accessible by shore and consists of a beautiful double reef. The first reef is shallower than the second reef and they are separated by a long sand strip.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Punt square is the beginning of the south coast of Bonaire. At this spot also starts the beautiful double reef. Dive over the first reef, to a depth of 25 meters to the next.
text.description2: You will find typical Bonairean life here. A reef full of hard and soft corals. Look carefully under the overhangs and perhaps find a nurse shark.

text.description1: The reef here is between 15 and 30 meters. Shallower and deeper you will find mainly sand. This spot is a bit difficult to access from the shore but good by boat.
text.description2: On the sand you might come across rays. Furthermore, you will see the typical life that Bonaire has to offer.

text.description1: The Hilma Hooker is a 236-foot Dutch freighter that has a long and varied history including being used as a drug runner. It sunk just offshore in 1984 and is now the most popular wreck dive on Bonaire.
text.description2: Living in and around the wreck are nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, anemones, and grouper.

text.description1: Thousand Steps is one of the most famous dive sites in all of Bonaire. Parking for this site is at the top of a cliff where you descend down 67 stairs with your gear on to access the beach. The long set of steps is where this site gets its name. A beautiful dive location.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: Angel city is an amazing double reef that runs parallel to the coast. It starts after a flat section at a depth of 5 meters and the first reef extends at about 18 meters. Then up to get to the next rift till 9 meters. The reefs are not far apart, allowing you to dive in an environment surrounded by reefs.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: A great shore accessible dive site that’s less crowded than some of the other more popular dive sites but still offers the experience of diving the double reef system.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, turtles, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrot fish, and grouper.

text.description1: This reef is named after Don Steward, one of the diving pioneers on Bonaire. It is a beautiful reef with all kinds of small plateaus if you dive down the rig for a long time.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Mi Dushi (My Sweetheart) is a beautiful wall that extends to 38 meters. It is located on the island of Klein Bonaire and its flat start makes it ideal for snorkelers as well.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot is only accessible by boat and the translation from Papiamentu is welcome home. It is a beautifully situated reef that is worth it both shallow and deep.
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: Aquarius is a beautiful double reef. Please note, the 2nd reef is quite deep and requires a bit of a swim, so keep a close eye on your air supply. It is a bit of a swim to the first drop off, while you look at the beautiful corals.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: A beautiful spot on Klein Bonaire, because you moor close to the coast, this spot is very suitable for diving and snorkeling. Depth of the reef is 6 to 30 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish

text.description1: A spot that starts with a flat stretch of sand before turning into a wall that continues for about 30 metres. For the experienced diver; cross the sand there to start at the next wall at about 28 meter.
text.description2: Here you will find various types of hard and soft coral, life on sand, and of course all the inhabitants of the Bonairean coral reefs.

text.description1: This dive site is located on Klein Bonaire and can only be reached by boat. Its structure makes it a fun and diverse spot for both snorkeling and diving for beginners and advanced.
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: If you look to the left, you can enjoy flamingos in the salt pans. On the other side you will find this dive site. You can only dive from the shore with calm water, swim down the sand flat and enjoy the wall!
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: Once intended to measure the impact of divers on the reefs, divers were banned from this reef. However, it is a beautiful reef that runs from about 9 to 30 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: The most westerly dive site on Klein Bonaire. Due to the gently sloping bottom, this site is also very suitable for snorkelers and beginning divers. Only from 12 meters the reef slopes steeper.
text.description2: You will encounter a lot of typical life for Bonaire here. From life on sand to a full-grown reef. At depth you will find a cleaning station.

elements.copyright: SSI Service Center Southern Caribbean,  Willemstad

text.description1: Active pier for loading salt from the salt works on the island of Bonaire. It can only be dived when no ship is moored, and no maintenance is being performed.
text.description2: Schooling fish can be found at each of the piers (multiple structures/platforms). Opportunities for barracuda, tarpon, and sea turtles.

text.description1: On the southwestern tip of Klein Bonaire you will find Forest. You can only get here by boat and either do a shallow dive or visit the reef, which extends to a depth of 50 meters.
text.description2: Besides the typical life on Klein Bonaire you will also find many black corals and some cleaning stations!

text.description1: With the limestone formations, Country Garden is highly recommended. A variety of fish swim around and between here. Please note, it is a real boat diving site that you cannot visit from the shore.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Salt City is the first place past the famous salt pier. It is a double reef as is often found on Bonaire. The reef is a nice change of sand and coral.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: An easily accessible shore dive with a double reef feature. The first reef is shallow and great for beginning divers and snorkelers. The second reef is a bit deeper and separated by a long, skinny sand flat.
text.description2: A great site to see garden eels in the sand channel between the reefs. Spotted drums, parrotfish, trunkfish and spotted eagle rays are also likely to be seen.

text.description1: Located in a small shallow bay with a coral beach. Also known as “Ol’ Blue“ due to the bright blue color of the water. Also good for non-divers because of the small beach.
text.description2: Lots of fan corals. Hermit crabs and peacock flounders in the sand. Hard and soft corals at and after the dropoff with lots of blue and midnight parrot fish.

text.description1: The reef here is almost impossible to reach from the shore, so its a must do by dive boat! It is a beautiful but steep reef with a sandy plateau.
text.description2: You will see typical Caribbean life such as nurse and reef sharks, possibly eagle rays, stingrays and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, parrotfish.

text.description1: The reef is located at a passage to the salt pans and is therefore easy to reach. Take a good look around along the way, there is a huge variety of fish on this reef!
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: In the past you could descend here using a rope, which is why the site still owes its name. Nowadays you can only go boat diving at this site. The reef has a beautiful shape and the coral is breathtaking.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish

text.description1: Pink Beach is a beautiful diving site, a typical southern site with a sandy area that merges into the reef. Feel free to bring non-diving family with you, they can lie on the beach and snorkel.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This spot is only accessible by boat. Do you still want to make a shore dive? Dare the jump and dive through to Karpata. It is a steep wall up to 30 meters, followed by a sandy plateau and the next wall up to about 60 meters.
text.description2: A beautiful pristine dive site with a beautiful healthy coral reef. Will you spot turtles or perhaps a Caribbean Reef Shark?

text.description1: Many consider Karpata one of the best dive sites in Bonaire. It is famous for its spectacular visibility and beautiful topography. The reef is covered in healthy soft and hard corals and the reef has beautiful shaping to it. A must dive while in Bonaire!
text.description2: A great site to spot sea turtles! You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Before the reef really starts you have a large stretch of sand that is also interesting for snorkelers. The reef itself is named after the schools of “Black Margate“ that you can encounter here.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Named for the old slave huts located here. Easiest entry is from near the second hut. Cross a long sand bank to reach the coral area. Look for eagle rays in the shallows.
text.description2: Eagle rays in the shallows. Soft corals and sponges between the sand and the drop off. Large elephant ear sponges.

text.description1: This site is located on the reef around the salt pans. It is a relatively shallow spot, which also makes it very suitable for snorkeling. Please note that there may be waves on windy days.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Excellent dive site but also overrun with kite surfers. Always send up an SMB before surfacing! Park on the road and enter just north of the wind pennant through a sandy channel.
text.description2: Crinoids, hard and soft corals. Eagle rays, tarpon, barracuda, palometas, cherub fish, and sargassum triggerfish.

text.description1: Attention! You can not park your car here on the beach because of turtle eggs (see the sign). Entering the water can be a bit difficult with the surf, swim over the sand and there begins the reef.
text.description2: You can definitely encounter turtles here! On the sand up to 10 meters or on the reef lives more of the beautiful Bonairean life!

text.description1: A beautiful spot where you can easily get into the water. It is flat for a while, after which you can follow a steep wall from about 9 meters away. NB! There can be big waves.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Named after the lighthouse here; the Willemstoren. It is one of the southernmost dive sites on Bonaire and a beautiful reef but the current can be strong.
text.description2: Due to the current there is a lot of soft coral and lots of large fish such as tarpons and barracudas.

text.description1: This dive site is located near the red slave huts. It is a site with a steep reef that is suitable for more experienced divers due to the current.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: A beautiful reef with lots of healthy coral! You will also find a lot of coral shallower, which makes snorkeling here a great experience. Pay attention on the entrance, it is littered with remains of coral.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Only a little diving is done at Tailor Made which you can see! The reef on which the wall starts at 9 meters and extends to 40 meters is largely unspoilt. Please note the long bumpy road to get there and there is no coverage.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This site is named after Carel Steensma, a resistance hero from the Second World War. He had a role in the establishment of the Washington Slagbaai Park.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish

text.description1: It is a less visited dive site, so as a diver you can really enjoy the pristine coral. You will regularly find sharks at the beginning of the dropoff.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Playa Frans is a fishing beach with some houses. A beautiful sloping reef with lots of life and also fun for snorkeling due to the large shallow areas.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Boca Slagbaai is a historic point where non-divers can also enjoy the bay, beach and snorkeling. Underwater you will find two old cannons and other objects.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish

text.description1: Wayaka, especially after a rainy period, can only be reached with a 4WD via the Washington Slagbaai National Park. There is little diving here, which means that the site is unspoilt.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This is the northernmost (official) dive site of Bonaire, but note that it is a more challenging dive site when the waves are high. The reef extends to a maximum of 40 meters.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: This reef starts shallow and from about 10 meters there is a dropoff to a sandy bottom. It is a site that is accessible from the shore or boat, but diving is usually done by boat.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Playa Funchi is a reef where there can be strong currents. In the water it is a bit of a swim from the beach. You can recognize remains of the foundation of an old plantation.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.

text.description1: Playa Benge is a reef up to 40 meters deep. It is a reef with grooves filled with sand. It is the second northernmost reef and can only be reached via the Washington Slangbaai National Park.
text.description2: You’ll see typical Caribbean life like nurse and reef sharks, possible eagle rays, stingrays, and lots of fish: snapper, angelfish, grunts, parrotfish.
